Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Backscatter Propagation-based Multi-hop Networks for Battery-less Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A backscatter communication enables development and implementation of battery-less sensors, miniaturized (MEMS) robots, or even nano devices. However, the current stat-of-the-art technology limits communication scenario to a direct transmission between active and passive devices, for example in radio frequency identification (RFID) system between a reader and a passive tag. In contrast, the goal of this project is to develop a novel multi-hop network that utilizes backscatter signal as communication for passive, battery-less devices. The objectives of this work include mathematical representation of such passive multi-hop networks and development of novel cross-layer communication protocols and control schemes with learning methodology for beam-forming. The expected contributions include an improved theoretical understanding of the multi-hop network of battery-less devices and a novel cross-layer optimization framework of network protocols that are feasible and practically viable. The end result of this effort would lead into a truly pervasive, backscatter-based networking paradigm.
The proposal?s outcomes include extending the range and improved capabilities of RFID systems to support larger and more complex sensing applications while lowering cost and minimizing environmental impacts (batteries-less operation). Moreover, a set of outreach activities include engagement of women and students from under-represented minorities through Missouri S&T Student Diversity Programs' office and Project Lead the Way (K-12 outreach). In long term, the outcomes will support various applications of MEMS and nano devices through facilitating a communication and control of such devices, with a potential to transform the healthcare, manufacturing into something that now is considered a science fiction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overall, the project both demonstrated and developed techniques that improve passive, battery-free Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) systems. The techniques enable a multi-hop and cooperative communication among passive, battery-free RFID tags. They have potential in replacing battery-operated sensor networks thus saving environment from dangerous waste while reducing operation and maintenance costs. In particular, the team has developed models for multi-hop passive RFID communication and a routing strategy that optimizes the network performance. It demonstrated that such multi-hop systems are able to compete in performance and communication range with traditional senor technologies while not requiring a battery.

The second technical outcome is a cooperative communication scheme for passive RFID systems, where multiple nearby tags improve communication performance in terms of increased communication distance and higher data rates. The traditional passive RFID systems operate at 10-30ft distances, even with 1W transmitters. The developed scheme can extend the range to over 50ft. The results have been demonstrated in theory and simulations. Moreover, it has been validated in experiments. Finally, the work has lead to collaboration with a small business with intention to commercialize the technology.

During the work at the project, we have identified a need for improving the RFID reliability in tracking object in metal-reach environment. For example, tracing metallic objects in logistics application or monitoring usage of components inside vehicles, for instance a car or an airplane (in particular in engine compartment, as shown in attached figure 1). The basic technique employs the same impedance switching capability developed for cooperative communication scheme that was discussed above. Our team demonstrated that the RFID tag with modified impedance matching network overcomes the radio communication challenges in a metal-rich environment. Moreover, it can continuously tune the impedance thus adjusting to different and changing configurations in the environment. For example, when components are moved in storage or in engine. The figure with ISN Gen 2 design illustrates the laboratory prototype of the impedance-switching network which was used to validate our research findings and developed technique. Future commercialization work aims at miniaturizing the design and integrating on the RFID tag chip (integrated circuit or IC).

Overall, the research has lead to development of useful models and techniques with commercial potential. The commercialization effort has been started with a small business company, TDA-I. This will result in broad economical benefits. Moreover, our improvements in RFID system and tag design have potential to replace traditional, battery-operated sensor devices with passive, battery-free RFID tags. Consequently, chemical and electronic waste due to battery replacement will be avoided.

Finally, the project funding supported over 7 graduate, 3 undergraduate, and 4 high school students – including 5 female engineers. They gained invaluable experience in conducting research and improving their analytical and communication skills. As results, they become successful engineers and researchers with thriving careers.
